label: trough
definition: A linear structural depression that extends laterally over a distance, while being less steep than a trench. A trough can be a narrow basin or a geologic rift. There are various oceanic troughs, troughs found under oceans; examples include the rift along the mid-oceanic ridge and the Cayman Trough.

label: beaver dam
definition: An obstruction in a stream constructed by a beaver.

label: submerged bed
definition: The portion of the ground surface which lies below water.

label: container of an intermittent saline lake
definition: A depression that is periodically filled with saline water, forming a saline lake.

label: container of an intermittent oxbow lake
definition: A depression which is continous with one or more abandoned meander loops of a river channel.

label: container of an intermittent pond
definition: A container of an intermittent water body which, when filled with water, has a well-illuminated surface layer, is subject to complete mixing of the water it holds, and is smaller than the container of a lake.

label: underground irrigation canal
definition: A gently inclined underground tunnel bringing water for irrigation from an aquifer.

label: intermittently filled reservoir
definition: A reservoir that is not permanently filled with water, at times being dry.

label: wadi mouth
definition: The lower terminus of a wadi where it widens into an adjoining floodplain, depression, or water body.

label: terrace
definition: A step-like feature between higher and lower ground: a relatively flat or gently inclined shelf of earth, backed and fronted by steep slopes or manmade detaining walls.

label: blanket bog
definition: A peatland whose development is mostly independent of basins or topographical features where water collects; it simply covers the landscape like a blanket. Peat develops due to a continuous supply of water from rainfall, maintaining waterlogged conditions on the ground. Blanket bogs are ombrotrophic or rain fed, and as a result their pH lies between 3.5 and 4.2.

label: pond bed
definition: The ground surface that lies beneath a pond.

label: reservoir bed
definition: The ground surface that lies beneath a reservoir.

label: crater
definition: A generally circular saucer or bowl-shaped depression caused by volcanic or meteorite explosive action.

label: road cut
definition: A cut to provide passage for a road.

label: hummock
definition: A patch of ground, distinct from and slightly above the surrounding plain or wetland. Often occurs in groups.

label: lost stream
definition: A surface stream that disappears into an underground channel, or dries up in an arid area.

label: ditch mouth
definition: The exit or point of discharge of a ditch.

label: landslide
definition: A mound of earth material, at the base of a slope and the associated scoured area.

label: rockfall
definition: An irregular mass of fallen rock at the base of a cliff or steep slope.

label: canal tunnel
definition: A tunnel through which a canal passes.

label: cutoff
definition: A channel formed as a result of a stream cutting through a meander neck.

label: abandoned watercourse
definition: A former stream or distributary no longer carrying flowing water, but still evident due to lakes, wetland, topographic or vegetation patterns.

label: canalized stream
definition: A stream that has been substantially ditched, diked, or straightened.

label: cleft
definition: A deep narrow slot, notch, or groove in a cliff.

label: interfluve
definition: A relatively undissected upland between adjacent stream valleys.

label: ice cap ridge
definition: A linear elevation on an icecap.

label: beach ridge
definition: A ridge of sand just inland and parallel to the beach, usually in series.

label: apron
definition: A gentle slope, with a generally smooth surface, particularly found around groups of islands and seamounts.

label: ice cap depression
definition: A depression which is part of an ice cap.

label: landfill
definition: A site at which refuse is dumped, normally filling a natural or artificial depression.

label: weir
definition: A low obstruction built across the path of s stream to raise its level.

label: moatan
definition: An annular depression that may not be continuous, located at the base of many seamounts, islands, and other isolated elevations.

label: boulder field
definition: A high altitude or high latitude bare, flat area covered with large angular rocks.

label: arrugado
definition: An undersea area of subdued corrugations.

label: sill
definition: The low part of a gap or saddle separating basins.

label: brackish lake
definition: A lake which is primarily composed of brackish water, having a higher salinity than fresh water but a lower salinity than marine water.

label: kame
definition: An irregularly shaped hill or mound composed of sorted or stratified sand and gravel that is deposited in contact with the glacial ice. It can have an irregular shape. Kames are often associated with kettles, and this is referred to as kame and kettle topography. When the ice retreats further, the delta kame often collapses. Kame terraces are frequently found along the side of a glacial valley and are the deposits of meltwater streams flowing between the ice and the adjacent valley side.

label: swale
definition: A depression which comprises a low tract of land, especially when moist or marshy.

label: leat
definition: A man-made watercourse, or makeshift aqueduct, often an artificial channel which supplies water to a watermill or its mill pond, collecting water from upstream of the mill so that the natural level of the driving water is above the level of the stream at the mill. Alternatively to may deliver water for mineral washing and concentration, irrigation or to a dye works.

label: shingle beach
definition: A beach which is armoured with pebbles or small to medium sized cobbles.

label: lake sediment
definition: Lake sediment is sediment which covers the bottom of a lake. Lake sediments are comprised mainly of clastic material (sediment of clay, silt, and sand sizes), organic debris, chemical precipitates, or combinations of these.

label: waterhole
definition: A pond, often temporary or seasonal, used as a drinking place by mammals and birds.

label: container of an intermittent water body
definition: A depression which is is periodically filled with water when water supply exceeds evapotranspiration and bed seepage.

label: endorheic basin
definition: A drainage basin from which there is no outflow of water, either on the surface as rivers, or underground by flow or diffusion through rock or permeable material.

label: talik
definition: An area of unfrozen ground surrounded by permafrost.

label: multipurpose dam
definition: A dam constructed for more than one purpose.

label: saddle dam
definition: An auxiliary dam constructed to confine the reservoir created by a primary dam either to permit a higher water elevation and storage or to limit the extent of a reservoir for increased efficiency.

label: check dam
definition: A dam designed to reduce flow velocity and control soil erosion.

label: wing dam
definition: A dam that only partly restricts a waterway, creating a faster channel that resists the accumulation of sediment.

label: dry dam
definition: A dam designed to control flooding. It normally holds back no water and allows the channel to flow freely, except during periods of intense flow that would otherwise cause flooding downstream.

label: diversionary dam
definition: A dam designed to divert all or a portion of the flow of a river from its natural course.

label: weapons test site
definition: A region at which weapons, typically military, are tested.

label: nuclear weapons test site
definition: A weapons test site at which nuclear weapons are, or have been, tested.

label: military training area
definition: A region in which military personnel train.

label: park
definition: A bounded area of land, or water, usually in its natural or semi-natural (landscaped) state and set aside for some purpose, usually to do with recreation or conservation.

label: pier
definition: A raised walkway over water, supported by piles or pillars.

label: archeological site
definition: A place (or group of physical sites) in which evidence of past activity is preserved (either prehistoric or historic or contemporary), and which is, has been, or may be, investigated using the discipline of archaeology.

label: sports facility
definition: A building or region where sports activities can be carried out.

label: winter sports facility
definition: A sports facility constructed for skiing and allied sports that require snow and/or ice.

label: calanque
definition: A deep valley with steep sides, typically of limestone, in part submerged by the sea.

label: obsolete aerial habitat
definition: A habitat that is solely in the air.

label: obsolete marine habitat
definition: A habitat that is in or on a sea or ocean containing high concentrations of dissolved salts and other total dissolved solids (typically >35 grams dissolved salts per litre).

label: obsolete brackish water habitat
definition: A habitat that is in or on a body of water (as in estuaries) containing medium concentrations of dissolved salts and other total dissolved solids (typically 0.5 to 35 grams dissolved salts per litre).

label: obsolete arboreal habitat
definition: A habitat in or on trees.

label: obsolete subterrestrial habitat
definition: A habitat that is below the surface of the earth.

label: city
definition: Incorporated populated place.

label: freshwater biome
definition: An aquatic biome which is determined by a body of freshwater.

label: obsolete Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest biome
obsolete Temperate grasslands, savannas, and shrubland biome
obsolete Mediterranean forests, woodlands, and shrub biome
obsolete Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forest biome
obsolete Tropical and subtropical dry broadleaf forest biome
obsolete Tropical and subtropical grasslands, savannas, and shrubland biome
obsolete Montane grasslands and shrubland biome
obsolete Deserts and xeric shrubland biome
obsolete Flooded grasslands and savanna biome
obsolete endolithic habitat
definition: A habitat consisting of the spaces within rocks, such as pores between aggregate grains. Inhabited by endolithic organisms.

label: xeric basin biome
definition: A biome which has little permanent surface water and a low relative abundance of springs.

label: obsolete temperate shelf and sea biome
rock
definition: A rock is a naturally occurring solid aggregate of one or more minerals or mineraloids.

label: mine drainage
definition: The outflow of water from a mine.

label: acid mine drainage
definition: A mine drainage with an acidic pH.

label: soil
definition: Soil is an environmental material which is primarily composed of minerals, varying proportions of sand, silt, and clay, organic material such as humus, gases, liquids, and a broad range of resident micro- and macroorganisms.

label: marine water body
definition: A significant accumulation of water which is part of a marine biome.

label: slope
definition: A solid astronomical body part which is part of the planetary surface between the peak of an elevation or the bottom of a depression and  relatively flat surrounding land.

label: waste water
definition: Water that has been adversely affected in quality by anthropogenic influence.

label: fecal material
definition: An excreta material which is composed primarily of feces, an excreta consisting of waste products expelled from an animal's digestive tract through the anus (or cloaca) during defecation.

label: obsolete physical object of mesoscopic geological size
definition: An object which is large enough to be visible to humans, but small enough that humans can handle the object (i.e. transport it, examine it, etc) in its entirety with little to no technological assistance.

label: air
definition: The mixture of gases (roughly (by molar content/volume: 78% nitrogen, 20.95% oxygen, 0.93% argon, 0.038% carbon dioxide, trace amounts of other gases, and a variable amount (average around 1%) of water vapor) that surrounds the planet Earth.

label: liquid water
definition: An environmental material primarily composed of dihydrogen oxide in its liquid form.

label: sediment
definition: Sediment is an environmental substance comprised of any particulate matter that can be transported by fluid flow and which eventually is deposited as a layer of solid particles on the bedor bottom of a body of water or other liquid.

label: dust
definition: Minute solid particles with diameters less than 500 micrometers. Occurs in and may be deposited from, the atmosphere.

label: obsolete terrestrial habitat
definition: A habitat that is on or at the boundary of the surface of the Earth.

label: saline water
definition: Water which contains a significant concentration of dissolved salts.

label: fresh water
definition: Water which has a low concentration of dissolved solutes, particularly that of sodium chloride.

label: hypersaline water
definition: Water which contains a highly increased concentration of dissolved salts, surpassing the average salinity of seawater.

label: igneous rock
definition: Rock formed from molten magma.

label: plutonic rock
definition: An igneous rock that results from the crystallization of a magma below the surface of the Earth.

label: volcanic rock
definition: An igneous rock that results from magma reaching the surface either as lava or fragmental ejecta.

label: sedimentary rock
definition: A rock formed by deposition of either clastic sediments, organic matter, or chemical precipitates (evaporites), followed by compaction of the particulate matter and cementation during diagenesis.

label: metamorphic rock
definition: A rock formed by subjecting any rock type (including previously-formed metamorphic rock) to different temperature and pressure conditions than those in which the original rock was formed. These temperatures and pressures are always higher than those at the Earth's surface and must be sufficiently high so as to change the original minerals into other mineral types or else into other forms of the same minerals (e.g. by recrystallisation).

label: sewage
definition: Wastewater that is contaminated with feces or urine,

label: brackish water
definition: Water which has a higher salinity than fresh water but a lower salinity than marine water.

label: obsolete extreme habitat
definition: A habitat having at least one environmental quality that tends towards either the largest or smallest element of the set. The physical or geochemical extreme conditions found in an extreme habitat are often detrimental to the majority of life on Earth.

label: obsolete acid habitat
definition: A habitat in which the pH is <pH3. Inhabited by acidophilic organisms.

label: obsolete alkaline habitat
definition: A habitat in which the pH is >pH9. Inhabited by alkaliphilic organisms.

label: obsolete high pressure habitat
definition: A habitat characterized by high gas or liquid pressure, inhabited by barophilic (piezophilic) organisms.

label: obsolete haline habitat
definition: A habitat characterized by a concentration of salt at least 2M. Inhabited by halophilic organisms.

label: obsolete high temperature habitat
definition: A habitat characterized by an average temperature of at least 60deg C. Inhabited by thermophilic organisms.

label: obsolete cold temperature habitat
definition: A habitat characterized by an average temperature of 15deg C or lower. Inhabited by psychrophilic (cryophilic) organisms.

label: obsolete extreme high temperature habitat
definition: A habitat characterized by an average temperature of at least 80deg C. Inhabited by hyperthermophilic organisms.

label: obsolete high osmolarity habitat
definition: A habitat characterized by a high osmolarity, typically the result of a high concentration of sugars. Inhabited by osmophilic organisms.

label: aquatic biome
definition: A biome which is determined by a water body and which has ecological climax communities adapted to life in or on water.

label: obsolete anthropogenic habitat
definition: A habitat that is in or on an environmental feature or material derived from human activity.

label: obsolete organism-associated habitat
definition: A habitat that is in or on a living thing.

label: carcass
definition: The dead body of an animal.

label: biofilm
definition: A complex aggregation of microorganisms marked by the excretion of a protective and adhesive matrix; usually adhering to a substratum.

label: meteorite
definition: A natural object originating in outer space that survives an impact with a planetary surface without being destroyed.

label: obsolete habitat
definition: A spatial region having environmental qualities which may sustain an organism or a community of organisms.

label: obsolete freshwater habitat
definition: A habitat that is in or on a body of water containing low concentrations of dissolved salts and other total dissolved solids (<0.5 grams dissolved salts per litre).

label: obsolete bone
definition: The rigid organs that form part of the endoskeleton of vertebrates.

label: surface water
definition: Water that is found on the surface of an astronomical object.

label: sludge
definition: The residual semi-solid material left from domestic or industrial processes, or wastewater treatment processes.

label: anaerobic sediment
definition: Sediment characterised by the absence of oxygen.

label: urine material
definition: An excreta material which is composed primarily of urine, a liquid excreta containing water and waste products made by the kidneys, stored in the bladder, and leaves the body through the urethra.

label: chondrite
definition: A stony meteorite that have not been modified due to melting or differentiation of the parent body.

label: achondrite
definition: A stony meteorite that is made of material similar to terrestrial basalts or plutonic rocks.

label: stony-iron meteorite
definition: A meteorite that consists of a mixture of iron-nickel metal and silicate minerals.

label: iron meteorite
definition: A meteorite that overwhelmingly of nickel-iron alloys.

label: limestone
definition: A sedimentary rock composed largely of the mineral calcite.

label: chalk
definition: A soft, white, porous limestone.

label: sandstone
definition: A sedimentary rock composed mainly of sand-size mineral or rock grains.

label: shale
definition: A fine-grained sedimentary rock whose original constituents were clays or muds. It is characterized by thin laminae breaking with an irregular curving fracture, often splintery and usually parallel to the often-indistinguishable bedding plane.

label: biosolids
definition: A treated form of sludge, sometimes used as a fertilizer in agriculture.

label: oil sludge
definition: A solid or gel in motor oil caused by the oil gelling or solidifying, usually at temperatures lower than 100deg C.

label: oil spill
definition: The result of the unintentional release of liquid petroleum hydrocarbon into the environment as a result of human activity.

label: obsolete oil
definition: OBSOLETE.

label: oil seep
definition: The result of the release of natural hydrocarbons to the surface of the earth, including beneath the sea, by natural geological processes.

label: deep marine sediment
definition: Sediment that accumulates in the flat or very gently sloping areas of the deep ocean basin floor. The three main types of deep marine sediment, also known as pelagic sediment, are siliceous oozes, calcareous oozes, and red clays.

label: chemically enriched sediment
definition: Sediment which has increased levels of one or more chemical compounds.

label: petroleum enriched sediment
definition: Organically enriched sediment which has increased levels of petroleum.

label: contaminated soil
definition: A portion of contaminated soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of some contaminant.

label: creosote contaminated soil
definition: Soil which has elevated concentrations of creosote.

label: alkaline hot spring
definition: A hot spring whose water has an alkaline pH.

label: acid hot spring
definition: A hot spring whose water has an acidic pH.

label: arsenic-rich mud
definition: Mud which has elevated concentrations of arsenic.

label: bioreactor
definition: A biomaterial containment unit which is capable of 1) containing a mass of environmental material which hosts an active collection of organisms and 2) maintaining conditions which are conducive to one or more metabolic activities of the organisms it contains.

label: anaerobic bioreactor
definition: A bioreactor in which the contained material is not oxygenated (i.e. void of biologically consequential free oxygen)

label: anaerobic dechlorinating bioreactor
definition: A device or system that supports a biologically active environment. A vessel in which is carried out a chemical process which involves organisms or biochemically active substances derived from such organisms. This process can either be aerobic or anaerobic.

label: aerobic bioreactor
definition: A bioreactor in which the contained material is well-oxygenated.

label: hypolimnion
definition: The dense, bottom layer of water in a thermally-stratified lake. It is the layer that lies below the thermocline.

label: epilimnion
definition: The top-most layer in a thermally stratified lake, occurring above the deeper hypolimnion. It is warmer and typically has a higher pH and dissolved oxygen concentration than the hypolimnion.

label: metalimnion
definition: A cline which is part of a lake and across which temperature changes rapidly with depth.

label: anaerobic mud
definition: Mud which has no or neglible concentrations of dissolved oxygen.

label: brackish estuary
definition: An estuary which is composed primarily of brackish water.

label: pebble
definition: A clastic rock with a particle size of 4 to 64 millimeters based on the Krumbein phi scale of sedimentology.

label: cobble
definition: A rock or rock fragment with a particle size between 64 and 256 mm.

label: leachate
definition: The liquid produced when water percolates through any permeable material. It can contain either dissolved or suspended material, or usually both.

label: cave wall
definition: A solid surface layer which 1)  forms part of the boundary between the cavity of a cave and its solid container and 2) is roughtly perpendicular to the cave floor.

label: chromate contaminated soil
definition: Soil which has elevated concentrations of chromate.

label: xylene contaminated soil
definition: Soil which has elevated concentrations of xylene.

label: coal mine lake sediment
definition: Coal mine lake sediment is lake sediment which covers the bottom of a coal mine lake.

label: sea water
definition: Water which has physicochemical properties that have been determined by the processes occuring in a sea or ocean.

label: coastal sea water
definition: Coastal sea water is sea water that is adjacent to a coast.

label: biofilter
definition: A bioreactor which captures and, through the biological processes maintained in the medium it contains, degrades pollutants.

label: Superfund site
definition: A highly contaminated site designated by the United States of America's Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act.

label: estuarine mud
definition: Mud which is part of an estuary.

label: fossil material
definition: A solid environmental material which is formed by the replacement of organic substances (including those in soils and sediments) with mineral material.

label: compost
definition: The aerobically decomposed remnants of organic materials.

label: hospital
definition: A hospital is a building in which health care services are  provided by specialized staff and equipment.

label: iron-reducing zone of petroleum contaminated sediment
definition: A zone within a portion of petroleum contaminated sediment within which iron-reducing processes occur.

label: naphthalene enriched sediment
definition: Organically enriched sediment which has increased levels of naphthalene.

label: neutral hot spring
definition: A hot spring whose water has a neutral pH.

label: nitrobenzene enriched sediment
definition: Organically enriched sediment which has increased levels of nitrobenzene.

label: oil tank
definition: A manufactured container within which oil or other petrochemical products are stored and which these products are usually transported to end users or further storage facilities.

label: animal litter
definition: Straw or other material strewn in an animal's enclosure (e.g. a stable) for it to sleep on and to absorb its faeces and urine.

label: aquarium
definition: An aquarium is a vivarium which simulates the submerged portions of an aquatic environment

label: saline water aquarium
definition: A saline water aquarium is an aquarium which contains saline water as its primary ecological medium.

label: fresh water aquarium
definition: A fresh water aquarium is an aquarium which contains fresh water as its primary ecological medium.

label: sea ice
definition: Water ice which has formed by the freezing of sea water.

label: cis-dichloroethane contaminated sediment
definition: Organically enriched sediment which has increased levels of cis-dichloroethane.

label: organically enriched sediment
definition: Chemically-enriched sediment which has increased levels of organic compounds.

label: inorganically enriched sediment
definition: Chemically-enriched sediment which has increased levels of inorganic compounds.

label: saline lake sediment
definition: Saline lake sediment is sediment which covers the bottom of a saline lake.

label: power plant
definition: A power plant is a building which contains one or more generators which convert mechanical energy into electrical energy through the relative motion between a magnetic field and a conductor. The energy source harnessed to turn the generator varies widely.

label: geothermal power plant
definition: A geothermal power plant is a power plant which uses heat generated by the decay of radioactive isotopes in the Earth's mantle and crust as well as primordial heat left over from the formation of the Earth to drive its generators.

label: shop
definition: A building in which a business presents a selection of goods and offers to trade or sell them to customers for money or other goods.

label: food shop
definition: A shop in which a business offers food products for sale or trade.

label: oligotrophic water
definition: Water with a very low nutrient level.

label: eutrophic water
definition: Water with a high nutrient level.

label: mesotrophic water
definition: Water with a nutrient level intermediate between eutrophic and oligotrophic.

label: borehole
definition: A channel which is constructed by removing materials from land or submerged beds.

label: obsolete saline water habitat
definition: A habitat that is in or on a body of water containing medium to high concentrations of dissolved salts and other total dissolved solids (>=0.5 grams dissolved salts per litre).

label: arenosol
definition: Arenosols are sandy soils, including both soils developed in residual sands after in situ weathering of usually quartz-rich sediments or rock, and soils developed in recently deposited sands such as dunes in deserts and beach lands.

label: anthrosol
definition: Anthrosols comprise soils that have been modified profoundly through human activities, such as addition of organic materials or household wastes, irrigation and cultivation.

label: alisol
definition: Alisols are soils that have a higher clay content in the subsoil than in the topsoil as a result of pedogenetic processes (especially clay migration) leading to an argic subsoil horizon. Alisols have a low base saturation at certain depths and high-activity clays throughout the argic horizon. They lack the albeluvic tonguing as in Albeluvisols. They occur predominantly in humid tropical, humid subtropical and warm temperate regions.

label: andosol
definition: Andosols are soils that develop in volcanic ejecta or glasses under almost any climate (except under hyperarid climate conditions). However, Andosols may also develop in other silicate-rich materials under acid weathering in humid and perhumid climates.

label: albeluvisol
definition: Albeluvisols are soils that have, beginning within 1 m of the soil surface, a clay illuviation horizon with an irregular or broken upper boundary resulting in tonguing of bleached soil material into the illuviation horizon.

label: acrisol
definition: Acrisols are soils that have a higher clay content in the subsoil than in the topsoil as a result of pedogenetic processes (especially clay migration) leading to an argic subsoil horizon. Acrisols have in certain depths a low base saturation and low-activity clays.

label: cambisol
definition: Cambisols combine soils with at least an incipient subsurface soil formation. Transformation of parent material is evident from structure formation and mostly brownish discoloration, increasing clay percentage, and/or carbonate removal.

label: cryosol
definition: Cryosols comprise mineral soils formed in a permafrost environment. Where water is present, it occurs primarily in the form of ice. Cryogenic processes are the dominant soil-forming processes.

label: chernozem
definition: Chernozems are soils with a thick black surface layer that is rich in organic matter.

label: durisol
definition: Durisols are associated mainly with old surfaces in arid and semi-arid environments and accommodate very shallow to moderately deep, moderately well- to well-drained soils that contain cemented secondary silica (SiO2) within 100 cm of the soil surface.

label: calcisol
definition: Calcisols are soils in which there is substantial secondary accumulation of lime. Calcisols are common in highly calcareous parent materials and widespread in arid and semi-arid environments.

label: kastanozem
definition: Kastanozems are dry grassland soils, among them the zonal soils of the short-grass steppe belt, south of the Eurasian tall-grass steppe belt with Chernozems. Kastanozems have a similar profile to that of Chernozems but the humus-rich surface horizon is thinner and not as dark as that of the Chernozems and they show more prominent accumulation of secondary carbonates.

label: leptosol
definition: Leptosols are very shallow soils over continuous rock and soils that are extremely gravelly and/or stony. Leptosols are azonal soils and particularly common in mountainous regions.

label: lixisol
definition: Lixisols are soils that have a higher clay content in the subsoil than in the topsoil as a result of pedogenetic processes (especially clay migration) leading to an argic subsoil horizon. Lixisols have a high base saturation and low-activity clays at certain depths.

label: histosol
definition: Histosols comprise soils formed in organic material. These vary from soils developed in predominantly moss peat in boreal, arctic and subarctic regions, via moss peat, reeds/ sedge peat (fen) and forest peat in temperate regions to mangrove peat and swamp forest peat in the humid tropics. Histosols are found at all altitudes, but the vast majority occurs in lowlands.

label: gleysol
definition: Gleysols are wetland soils that, unless drained, are saturated with groundwater for long enough periods to develop a characteristic gleyic colour pattern. This pattern is essentially made up of reddish, brownish or yellowish colours at ped surfaces and/or in the upper soil layer or layers, in combination with greyish/bluish colours inside the peds and/or deeper in the soil.

label: gypsisol
definition: Gypsisols are soils with substantial secondary accumulation of gypsum (calcium sulfate). These soils are found in the driest parts of the arid climate zone.

label: ferralsol
definition: Ferralsols represent the classical, deeply weathered, red or yellow soils of the humid tropics. These soils have diffuse horizon boundaries, a clay assemblage dominated by low-activity clays (mainly kaolinite) and a high content of sesquioxides.

label: nitisol
definition: Nitisols are deep, well-drained, red, tropical soils with diffuse horizon boundaries and a subsurface horizon with more than 30 percent clay and moderate to strong angular blocky structure elements that easily fall apart into characteristic shiny, polyhedric (nutty) elements. Weathering is relatively advanced but Nitisols are far more productive than most other red, tropical soils.

label: luvisol
definition: Luvisols are soils that have a higher clay content in the subsoil than in the topsoil as a result of pedogenetic processes (especially clay migration) leading to an argic subsoil horizon. Luvisols have high-activity clays throughout the argic horizon and a high base saturation at certain depths.

label: phaeozem
definition: Phaeozems accommodate soils of relatively wet grassland and forest regions in moderately continental climates. Phaeozems are much like Chernozems and Kastanozems but are leached more intensively. Consequently, they have dark, humus rich surface horizons that, in comparison with Chernozems and Kastanozems, are less rich in bases. Phaeozems may or may not have secondary carbonates but have a high base saturation in the upper metre of the soil.

label: plinthosol
definition: Plinthosols are soils with plinthite, petroplinthite or pisoliths. Plinthite is an Fe-rich (in some cases also Mn-rich), humus-poor mixture of kaolinitic clay (and other products of strong weathering such as gibbsite) with quartz and other constituents that changes irreversibly to a layer with hard nodules, a hardpan or irregular aggregates on exposure to repeated wetting and drying. Petroplinthite is a continuous, fractured or broken sheet of connected, strongly cemented to indurated nodules or mottles. Pisoliths are discrete strongly cemented to indurated nodules. Both petroplinthite and pisoliths develop from plinthite by hardening.

label: planosol
definition: Planosols are soils with a light-coloured, surface horizon that shows signs of periodic water stagnation and abruptly overlies a dense, slowly permeable subsoil with significantly more clay than the surface horizon.

label: solonchak
definition: Solonchaks are soils that have a high concentration of soluble salts at some time in the year. Solonchaks are largely confined to the arid and semi-arid climate zones and to coastal regions in all climates.

label: umbrisol
definition: Umbrisols are soils in which organic matter has accumulated within the mineral surface soil (in most cases with low base saturation) to the extent that it significantly affects the behaviour and utilization of the soil.

label: vertisol
definition: A soil in which there is a high content of expansive clay known as montmorillonite that forms deep cracks in drier seasons or years. Alternate shrinking and swelling causes self-mulching, where the soil material consistently mixes itself, causing vertisols to have an extremely deep A horizon and no B horizon.

label: solonetz
definition: Solonetz are soils with a dense, strongly structured, clayey subsurface horizon that has a high proportion of adsorbed Na and/or Mg ions. Solonetz that contain free soda (Na2CO3) are strongly alkaline (field pH > 8.5).

label: regosol
definition: Regosols form a taxonomic remnant group containing all soils that could not be accommodated in any of the other RSGs. In practice, Regosols are very weakly developed mineral soils in unconsolidated materials that do not have a mollic or umbric horizon, are not very shallow or very rich in gravels (Leptosols), sandy (Arenosols) or with fluvic materials (Fluvisols). Regosols are extensive in eroding lands, particularly in arid and semi-arid areas and in mountainous terrain.

label: podzol
definition: Podzols are soils with a typically ash-grey upper subsurface horizon, bleached by loss of organic matter and iron oxides, on top of a dark accumulation horizon with brown, reddish or black illuviated humus and/or reddish Fe compounds. Podzols occur in humid areas in the boreal and temperate zones and locally also in the tropics.

label: loam
definition: A soil composed of sand, silt, and clay in relatively even concentration (about 40-40-20% concentration respectively).

label: forest soil
definition: A portion of soil which is found in a forested area.

label: garden soil
definition: A portion of soil which is found in a garden.

label: waste material
definition: A material which is not the desired output of a process and which is typically the input of a process which removes it from its producer (e.g. a disposal process).

label: obsolete agricultural waste
definition: Wastewater produced in the course of agricultural activities

label: industrial waste material
definition: Industrial wastes are liquid, solid and gaseous wastes originating from the manufacture of specific products.

label: sphagnum bog
definition: A peatland dominated by species of the Bryophyte Sphagnum.

label: thermocline
definition: A cline across which temperature changes rapidly.

label: chemocline
definition: A cline across which the chemical composition of a fluid changes rapidly.

label: nuclear power plant
definition: A nuclear power plant is a power plant which uses heat generated by a radioactive decay in a nuclear reactor to convert water into steam in order to drive turbines in electrical generators through pressure.

label: fluvisol
definition: Fluvisols accommodate genetically young, azonal soils in alluvial deposits.

label: stagnosol
definition: Stagnosols are soils with a perched water table showing redoximorphic features caused by surface water. Stagnosols are periodically wet and mottled in the topsoil and subsoil, with or without concretions and/or bleaching.

label: technosol
definition: Technosols are soils whose properties and pedogenesis are dominated by their technical origin. They contain a significant amount of artefacts (something in the soil recognizably made or extracted from the earth by humans), or are sealed by technic hard rock (material created by humans, having properties unlike natural rock). They include soils from wastes (landfills, sludge, cinders, mine spoils and ashes), pavements with their underlying unconsolidated materials, soils with geomembranes and constructed soils in human-made materials.

label: back-arc basin
definition: A depression in the sea floor that results from the collision of continental plates; the weight of the sinking plate causes the overlying plate to stretch and thin, causing a basin in the overlying plate. Sometimes, the Earth's crust in these basins stretches so much it cracks, allowing magma through from the mantle beneath. Hence, basins often contain active volcanoes and hydrothermal vents.

label: environmental feature
definition: A material entity which determines an environmental system.

label: ocean basin
definition: A structural basin that is below sea level.

label: hay
definition: Hay is grass, legumes or other herbaceous plants that have been cut, dried, and stored for use as animal fodder, particularly for grazing livestock such as cattle, horses, goats, and sheep.

label: adobe
definition: A natural building material mode from sand, clay, water, and some kind of fibrous or organic material (sticks, straw, and/or manure).

label: alluvial soil
definition: Soil which has been eroded and influenced by flowing water and redeposited in a non-marine setting.

label: bagasse
definition: The biomass remaining after sugarcane stalks are crushed to extract their juice.

label: oil contaminated soil
definition: Soil which has elevated concentrations of oil.

label: clay
definition: A group of hydrous aluminium phyllosilicate (phyllosilicates being a subgroup of silicate minerals) minerals (see clay minerals), that are typically less than 2 micrometres in diameter. Clay consists of a variety of phyllosilicate minerals rich in silicon and aluminium oxides and hydroxides which include variable amounts of structural water.

label: fuel oil
definition: An oil which 1) is liquid at room temperature (approximately 20 degrees Celsius) 2) is intended to be burned in a furnace or boiler for the generation of heat or used in an engine for the generation of power, 3) is obtained from petroleum distillation, either as a distillate or a residue, 4) composed of long hydrocarbon chains, particularly alkanes, cycloalkanes and aromatics.

label: petroleum
definition: A naturally occurring flammable liquid consisting of a complex mixture of hydrocarbons of various molecular weights and other liquid organic compounds, that are found in geologic formations beneath the planetary surfaces.

label: oil
definition: A nonpolar, hydrophobic, and lipophilic material which is a viscous liquid at ambient temperatures (about 20 degrees Celsius) or slightly warmer.

label: obsolete Evergreen sclerophyllous forests, scrub, or woodlands
obsolete Temperate broad-leaf forests or woodlands and subpolar deciduous thickets
obsolete Tropical dry or deciduous forests (including Monsoon forests) or woodlands
obsolete Subtropical and temperate rainforests or woodlands
obsolete Temperate needle-leaf forests or woodlands
obsolete Tundra communities and barren Arctic deserts
obsolete Mixed mountain and highland systems with complex zonation
obsolete Warm Continental Division - Mountain Provinces (M210)
obsolete Hot Continental Division - Mountain Provinces (M220)
obsolete Temperate Desert Division - Mountain Provinces (M340)
obsolete Temperate Steppe Division - Mountain Provinces (M330)
obsolete Tropical/Subtropical Steppe Division - Mountain Provinces (M310)
silage
definition: A fermented, high-moisture forage that can be fed to ruminants.

label: mushroom compost
definition: A compost which generally consists of a combination of wheat straw, dried blood, horse manure and ground chalk, composted together and is the residual compost waste generated by industrial mushroom production.

label: animal house
definition: A house used for sheltering non-human animals.

label: cow shed
definition: An animal house which is used to shelter cows.

label: piggery
definition: An animal house which is used to house pigs.

label: brine
definition: Water saturated or nearly saturated with salt (NaCl).

label: drinking water
definition: Drinking water is water which may be consumed by humans with no adverse effects on their health.

label: manufactured product
definition: A material entity that has been processed by humans or their technology in any way, including intermediate products as well as final products.

label: glue
definition: Glue is any substance applied to the surfaces of materials that binds them together and resists separation.

label: metal contaminated soil
definition: Soil which has elevated concentrations of metals.

label: enriched soil
definition: A portion of enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of some material entity.

label: sarcosine enriched soil
definition: A portion of sarcosine enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of sarcosine.

label: trimethylamine enriched soil
definition: A portion of trimethylamine enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of trimethylamine.

label: skatole enriched soil
definition: A portion of skatole enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of skatole.

label: ethanol enriched soil
definition: A portion of ethanol enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of ethanol.

label: acetamide enriched soil
definition: A portion of acetamide enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of acetamide.

label: pantothenate enriched soil
definition: A portion of pantothenate enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of pantothenate.

label: testosterone enriched soil
definition: A portion of testosterone enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of testosterone.

label: kynurenate enriched soil
definition: A portion of kynurenate enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of kynurenate.

label: threonine enriched soil
definition: A portion of threonine enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of threonine.

label: salicylate enriched soil
definition: A portion of salicylate enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of salicylate.

label: poly-beta-hydroxybutyrate enriched soil
definition: A portion of poly-beta-hydroxybutyrate enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of poly-beta-hydroxybutyrate.

label: L-(+)-tartrate enriched soil
definition: A portion of L-(+)-tartrate enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of L-(+)-tartrate.

label: quinate enriched soil
definition: A portion of quinate enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of quinate.

label: tannery
definition: A tannery is a building in which the skins of animals are treated with chemicals to alter the structure of their constituent proteins, creating leather.

label: pig manure
definition: Manure which is primarily composed of pig feces.

label: industrial building
definition: An industrial building is a building within which goods are produced and, optionally, stored or within which services are rendered.

label: dairy
definition: A dairy is a building in which animal milk is harvested and, optionally, processed for human consumption.

label: food processing building
definition: A food processing building is a building in which materials that contain or consist of essential body nutrients - such as carbohydrates, fats, proteins, vitamins, or minerals - and may be ingested and assimilated by an organism to produce energy, stimulate growth, and maintain life are converted alternative forms.

label: bakery
definition: A bakery is a building in which raw flour-based food is baked in an oven to produce food products such as bread, cakes, pastries, and pies. These products are often sold from the bakery itself.

label: straw
definition: An agricultural byproduct, the dry stalk of a cereal plant, after the nutrient grain or seed has been removed.

label: brewery
definition: A brewery is a building in which alcoholic beverages are produced by brewing, that is, steeping a starch source (commonly cereal grains) in water and fermenting the resulting sweet liquid with yeast. At times, the products are also sold from the brewery.

label: sake brewery
definition: A sake brewery is a brewery which produces rice wine by fermenting rice which has been polished to remove the bran.

label: research station
definition: A building or collection of co-located buildings constructed for the purpose of undertaking scientific research.

label: scum
definition: A layer of impurities that accumulates at the surface of a liquid (especially water or molten metal).

label: warehouse
definition: A warehouse is a building which is used for the storage of goods.

label: tobacco warehouse
definition: A tobacco warehouse is a warehouse used to store cured leaves of plants from the genus Nicotiana, primarily  N. tabacum and N. rustica.

label: creamery
definition: A creamery is a part of a dairy where cream is separated from whole milk.

label: air filter
definition: An air filter is a device that removes some substance from air.

label: travertine
definition: A natural chemical precipitate of carbonate minerals; typically aragonite, but often recrystallized to or primarily calcite; which is deposited from the water of mineral springs (especially hot springs) or streams saturated with calcium carbonate.

label: sawmill
definition: A building within which logs are cut into lumber products.

label: karst field
definition: A large flat plain in karst territory with areas usually 5 to 400 sqaure kilometres.

label: roadside soil
definition: A portion of soil which is found in a roadside area.

label: allotment garden soil
definition: Soil which is part of an allotment garden.

label: savanna soil
definition: A portion of soil which is found in a savanna.

label: dry soil
definition: Soil which has little to no water content and in which minerals and other soluble chemical entities have either bonded or become adsorbed to sold particles due to insufficient water availability.

label: farm soil
definition: A portion of soil which is part of a cropland or a rangeland biome.

label: grassland soil
definition: A portion of soil which is found in a grassland.

label: jungle soil
definition: Soil which is part of a densely forested area subject to tropical climate patterns.

label: urea enriched soil
definition: A portion of urea enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of urea.

label: bacteria enriched soil
definition: A portion of bacteria enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated bacterial abundance.

label: alluvial swamp soil
definition: A portion of alluvial soil which is part of a swamp ecosystem.

label: chloropicrin enriched soil
definition: A portion of chloropicrin enriched soil is a portion of soil with elevated levels of chloropicrin.

label: manured soil
definition: Soil which has, as a part, a portion of either fresh or processed animal manure.

label: orchid soil
definition: Soil which has properties to which plants in the Family Orchidaceae have adapted, including increased levels of aeration and drainage.

label: muddy soil
definition: Soil which is composed of a large proportion of mud, thus having properties resembling mud.

label: orchard soil
definition: Soil in which trees from an orchard grow.

label: pasture soil
definition: Soil which is found in a pasture and in which vegetation, such as the grass used for the grazing of ungulates, grows.

label: salt contaminated soil
definition: Soil which has elevated concentrations of sodium chloride.

label: steppe soil
definition: A portion of soil which is found in a steppe.

label: greenhouse soil
definition: A portion of soil which is found in a greenhouse.

label: ornithogenic soil
definition: Soil which is formed from avian fecal matter.

label: bluegrass field soil
definition: Bluegrass field soil is a soil which is found in a field of Kentucky Bluegrass (Poa pratensis).

label: sterile water
definition: Sterile water is water which does not contain lliving organisms.

label: underground water
definition: Water which has physicochemical properties determined by processes which occur beneath the planetary crust.

label: marine mud
definition: Mud which is part of a marine ecosystem.

label: lake bottom mud
definition: Mud which constitutes the bed of a lake.

label: desert sand
definition: Sand which is part of a desert.

label: rhizosphere
definition: The narrow region of soil that is directly influenced by root secretions and associated soil microorganisms.

label: bulk soil
definition: Soil that is not penetrated by the root systems of plants.

label: animal habitation
definition: The dwelling of an animal or group of similar animals.

label: nest of ant
definition: A pile of earth, sand, pine needles, or clay or a composite of these and other materials that build up at the entrances of the subterranean dwellings of ant colonies as they are excavated. A colony is built and maintained by legions of worker ants, who carry tiny bits of dirt and pebbles in their mandibles and deposit them near the exit of the colony. They normally deposit the dirt or vegetation at the top of the hill to prevent it from sliding back into the colony, but in some species they actively sculpt the materials into specific shapes, and may create nest chambers within the mound.

label: nest of bird
definition: A bird nest is the spot in which a bird lays and incubates its eggs and raises its young.

label: obsolete Tropical and subtropical coniferous forest biome
obsolete animal-associated habitat
definition: A habitat that is in or on a living animal. Here "animal" denotes an individual of a species that is a sub-taxon of NCBITaxon:33208.

label: obsolete plant-associated habitat
definition: A habitat that is in or on a living plant. Here "plant" denotes an individual of a species that is a sub-taxon of NCBITaxon:33090 (viridiplantae).

label: obsolete mammalia-associated habitat
definition: A habitat that is in or on a living mammal. Here "mammal" denotes an individual of a species that is a sub-taxon of NCBITaxon:40674.

label: obsolete human-associated habitat
definition: A habitat that is in or on a living animal. Here "animal" denotes an individual of a species that is a sub-taxon of NCBITaxon:9606.

label: obsolete insecta-associated habitat
definition: A habitat that is in or on a living insect. Here "insect" denotes an individual of a species that is a sub-taxon of NCBITaxon:50557.

label: ice rise
definition: An ice rise is an elevation which is part of an ice shelf, typically dome shared, and formed by the ice shelf overriding an obstruction in the seabed. An ice rise may be adjacent only to an ice shelf, or to an ice shelf and a sea. For some features, properly ice rises, the term island has become established through usage.

label: ice piedmont
definition: A glacier covering a coastal strip of low-lying land backed by mountains, and sloping gently seaward over a distance up to 30km or more to terminate in ice cliffs or to merge with an ice shelf.

label: strand crack
definition: Fissure at the junction between an inland ice sheet, ice piedmont or ice rise and an ice shelf, the latter being subject to the rise and fall of the tide.

label: fomite
definition: A fomite is any inanimate object or substance capable of carrying infectious organisms (such as germs or parasites) and hence transferring them from one individual to another. A fomite can be anything such as a cloth or mop heads so when cleaning this is important to remember that this could aid when spreading pathogenic organisms.

label: midden
definition: A dump for domestic waste. A term used to describe any kind of feature containing waste products relating to day-to-day human life.

label: environmental material
definition: A portion of environmental material is a fiat object part which forms the medium or part of the medium of an environmental system.

label: surface layer
definition: A layer of some material entity which is adjacent to one or more of its external boundaries and directly interacts with its immediate surroundings.

label: aerosol
definition: Airborne solid particles (also called dust or particulate matter (PM)) or liquid droplets.

label: emulsion
definition: A mixture of two immiscible (unblendable) substances. One substance (the dispersed phase) is dispersed in the other (the continuous phase).

label: vivarium
definition: A vivarium is an enclosure for keeping and raising organisms for observation or research. Often, a portion of the ecosystem for a particular species is simulated on a smaller scale, with controls for environmental conditions.

label: dolomite
definition: A sedimentary carbonate rock and a mineral, both composed of calcium magnesium carbonate CaMg(CO3)2 found in crystals.

label: botanical garden
definition: A place where a wide variety of plants primarily categorized and documented for scientific purposes.

label: zoological garden
definition: A facility in which animals are confined within enclosures and displayed to the public, and in which they may also be bred.

label: ocean time series station
definition: A research facility consisting of instruments that measure the properties of the oceans over time. Usually of at least approximately fixed location.

label: aquifer
definition: An underground layer of water-bearing permeable rock or unconsolidated materials (gravel, sand, silt, or clay) from which groundwater can be usefully extracted using a water well.

label: anthropogenic environmental material
definition: Anthropogenic material in or on which organisms may live.

label: obsolete beverage product
definition: A liquid  which is specifically prepared for human consumption.

label: obsolete sea water fish egg product
humus
definition: Organic matter in soil which has reached a point of stability, where it will break down no further and might, if conditions do not change, remain essentially as it is for centuries, or millennia.

label: mud
definition: A liquid or semi-liquid mixture of water and some combination of soil, silt, and clay.

label: water well
definition: A well which provides access to groundwater held  in an aquifer.

label: concentration basin mediterranean sea biome
definition: The concentration basin mediterranean sea biome comprises expressions of the mediterranean sea biome that have higher salinity than bordering oceans due to evaporation. Water exchange consists of inflow of the fresher oceanic water in the upper layer and outflow of the saltier mediterranean water in the lower layer of the connecting channel.

label: upwelling
definition:
MERGED DEFINITION:
TARGET DEFINITION: An oceanographic feature that involves wind-driven motion of dense, cooler, and usually nutrient-rich water towards the ocean surface, replacing the warmer, usually nutrient-deplete surface water.
--------------------
SOURCE DEFINITION: A marine upwelling is a net flow of marine water to the surface of the water column from deeper regions. This is often a result of surface water displacement off continental coasts by wind action. Localised upwellings may also occur along divergent fronts around eddies and along some of the major oceanographic features. Deeper waters often have higher nutrient content; consequently blooms of primary producers, such as planktonic algae, are generally observed around upwelling zones.

label: coastal upwelling
definition: An upwelling that is near a coast.

label: organic object formed through microbial activity
definition: An organic object which is formed as a result of the biological processes mediated by microbial assemblages.

label: microbial mat
definition: A multi-layered sheet of micro-organisms, mainly bacteria and archaea. Microbial mats grow at interfaces between different types of material, mostly on submerged or moist surfaces but a few survive in deserts.

label: silt
definition: Silt is granular material of a size somewhere between sand and clay whose mineral origin is quartz and feldspar.

label: sand
definition: A naturally occurring granular material composed of finely divided rock and mineral particles.

label: gravel
definition: Gravel is an environmental material which is composed of pieces of rock that are at least two millimeters (2mm) in its largest dimension and no more than 75 millimeters.

label: cave floor
definition: A solid surface layer which 1) forms part of the boundary between the cavity of a cave and its solid container and 2)  is the closest solid boundary to the gravitational centre of the astronomical body of which the cave is a part.

label: estuarine biome
definition: Expressions of the estuarine biome occur at wide lower courses of a rivers where they flow into a sea. Estuaries experience tidal flows and their water is a changing mixture of fresh and salt.

label: obsolete mangrove biome
definition: Expressions of the mangrove biome are typically found in tropical and sub-tropical tidal areas, in depositional coastal environments where fine sediments (often with high organic content) collect in areas protected from high energy wave action. A variety of characteristic trees and shrubs occur here and are able to withstand a high degree of salinity as well as regions of anoxia and frequent tidal inundation. These areas include estuaries and marine shorelines.

label: marine salt marsh biome
definition: The marine salt marsh biome comprises marshes that are transitional intertidals between land and salty or brackish marine water (e.g.: sloughs, bays, estuaries). It is dominated by halophytic (salt tolerant) herbaceous plants. The daily tidal surges bring in nutrients, which tend to settle in roots of the plants within the salt marsh. The natural chemical activity of salty (or brackish) water and the tendency of algae to bloom in the shallow unshaded water also allow for great biodiversity.

label: marine pelagic biome
definition: The marine pelagic biome (pelagic meaning open sea) is that of the marine water column, from the surface to the greatest depths.

label: marine benthic biome
definition: The marine benthic biome (benthic meaning 'bottom') encompasses the seafloor and includes such areas as shores, littoral or intertidal areas, marine coral reefs, and the deep seabed.

label: marine neritic benthic zone biome
definition: The marine neritic zone biome comprises sea floor from the high tide mark to a continental shelf break. This zone generally extends to 200 m below average sea level.

label: marine bathyal zone biome
definition: The marine bathyal zone biome comprises regions of the marine benthic biome between approximately 200 m and 3000 m depth. This zone generally coincides with the continental slope.

label: marine abyssal zone biome
definition: The marine abyssal zone biome comprises regions of the marine benthic biome  between approximately 2500 m and 6000 m depth. This zone generally coincides with the continental rise and the abyssal plain.

label: marine hadal zone biome
definition: The marine hadal zone biome describes sea floor deeper than 6000 m such as that of the oceanic trenches.

label: marine reef biome
definition: A biome expressed by strips or ridges of rocks, sand, or coral that rises to or near the surface of a body of marine water.

label: marine hydrothermal vent biome
definition: The marine hydrothermal vent biome comprises regions of the marine benthic biome where heat generated due to tectonic activity, either at divergent plate boundaries or convergent ocean plates where back-arc spreading occurs, is released or 'vented' to the surface. The resultant high temperature water jets are laden with dissolved metals and minerals.

label: obsolete marine feature
definition: A prominent or distinctive aspect, quality, or characteristic of a marine biome.

label: neritic pelagic zone biome
definition: The neritic epipelagic zone biome comprises the marine water column above a continental shelf.

label: oceanic pelagic zone biome
definition: The oceanic epipelagic zone biome comprises the marine water column offshore, beyond a continental shelf.

label: oceanic sea surface microlayer biome
definition: The oceanic sea surface microlayer (SML) biome comprises the top 1000 micrometers of the marine surface waters occurring offshore, away from a continental shelf. It is the boundary layer where all exchange occurs between the atmosphere and the ocean. The chemical, physical, and biological properties of the SML differ greatly from the sub-surface water just a few centimeters beneath.

label: oceanic epipelagic zone biome
definition: The oceanic epipelagic zone biome comprises regions of the marine water column that occur offshore, beyond a continental shelf. This biome extends from the surface of the ocean to a depth of ca. 200-250m. Throughout the zone the light field tends to be asymmetrical vertically, so that the direction and elevation of the sun can still be detected. The oceanic epipelagic zone biome encompasses the euphotic zone and, where and when it occurs, the seasonal thermocline.

label: oceanic mesopelagic zone biome
definition: The oceanic mesopelagic zone biome comprises regions of the marine water column that occur offshore, beyond a continental shelf. This biome extends through the water column from approximately 200-1000 m depth - the maximal depth of light penetration in all but the clearest oligotrophic ocean regions. In comparison to the epipelagic zone, dominant forms of pelagic organisms do not change very much; however, there are marked changes in species composition and the proportion of smaller-sized individuals decreases.

label: oceanic bathypelagic zone biome
definition: The bathypelagic zone biome comprises the marine water column below approximately 1000 m water depth - the maximum depth to which detectable daylight penetrates in all but the clearest oligotrophic waters - and extends to about 2500 - 2700 m water depth. In the temperate Atlantic, the beginning of the bathypelagic zone biome approximates to the deep oxygen minimum and the base of the permanent thermocline.

label: oceanic abyssopelagic zone biome
definition: The abyssopelagic zone biome comprises the marine water column below the bathypelagic zone biome at approximately 2500 -2700 m and extends either to the hadal pelagic zone biome (at approximately 6000 m) or to the benthopelagic zone biome within ca. 100 m of the seafloor. The depth of 2700 m may be critical for physiological reasons as the change in hydrostatic pressure across this depth may preclude organism migration.

label: oceanic hadal pelagic zone biome
definition: The oceanic hadal pelagic zone biome comprises the water column in oceanic trenches occurring at depths between 6000m and 10,000m.

label: oceanic benthopelagic zone biome
definition: The benthopelagic zone biome comprises regions of the marine water column which usually coincide with the benthic boundary layer (BBL) - the layer of isothermal and isohaline water contiguous to the sea floor. A general reversal in the declining gradient of pelagic biomass may be observed here, perhaps explained by viable nutrition on the sea floor being resuspended by bottom currents. This zone typically extends 100 m above the seafloor, but may reach upto1000 m during benthic storms.

label: neritic sea surface microlayer biome
definition: The neritic sea surface microlayer (SML) biome comprises the top 1000 micrometers of marine surface waters occurring above a continental shelf. It is the boundary layer where all exchange occurs between the atmosphere and the ocean. The chemical, physical, and biological properties of the SML differ greatly from the sub-surface water just a few centimeters beneath.

label: neritic epipelagic zone biome
definition: The neritic epipelagic zone biome comprises the marine water column that occurs above a continental shelf and extends from the surface of the ocean to a depth of ca. 200-250m. Throughout the zone the light field tends to be asymmetrical vertically, so that the direction and elevation of the sun can still be detected. The epipelagic zone encompasses the euphotic zone and, where and when it occurs, the seasonal thermocline.

label: neritic mesopelagic zone biome
definition: The neritic mesopelagic zone biome comprises the marine column that occurs above a continental shelf and extends from approximately 200 to 1000 m depth - the maximal depth of light penetration in all but the clearest oligotrophic ocean regions. In comparison to the epipelagic zone, dominant forms of pelagic organisms do not change very much; however, there are marked changes in species composition and the proportion of smaller-sized individuals decreases.

label: marine pelagic feature
definition: A prominent or distinctive aspect, quality, or characteristic of environments occurring within the marine water column.

label: epeiric sea biome
definition: The epeiric sea (also known as an epicontinental sea) biome comprises a shallow seas that extend over part of a continent. Epeiric seas are usually associated with the marine transgressions of the geologic  past, which have variously been due to either global eustatic sea level changes, local tectonic deformation, or both, and are occasionally semi-cyclic.

label: marginal sea biome
definition: The marginal sea biome comprises parts of an ocean partially enclosed by land such as islands, archipelagos, or peninsulas. Unlike mediterranean seas, marginal seas have ocean currents caused by ocean winds. Many marginal seas are enclosed by island arcs that were formed from the subduction of one oceanic plate beneath another.

label: mediterranean sea biome
definition: The mediterranean sea biome comprises mostly enclosed seas that have limited exchange of deep water with outer oceans and where the water circulation is dominated by salinity and temperature differences rather than winds.

label: ocean biome
definition: A marine biome which is determined by an ocean.

label: marine coral reef biome
definition: The marine coral reef biome comprises constructional wave-resistant entities which are primarily built by corals and are often cemented together. The growth of these structures is aided by zooxanthellae, algae that are symbiotic with the reef-building corals.

label: marine subtidal rocky reef biome
definition: The marine rocky subtidal reef biome comprises regions of the marine reef biome composed mainly of rock and which harbour abundant communities of algae and invertebrates. These reefs are often very patchy, with alterations of rocks dominated by rich invertebrate assemblages and turf-forming calcareous red algae.

label: marine black smoker biome
definition: A marine black smoker biome comprises regions of the marine hydrothermal vent biome characterised by a black vent plume. This black plume is a consequence of dissolved metals and minerals forming complexes with sulphide and indicates polymetallic sulphide mineral deposits beneath the surface.

label: marine white smoker biome
definition: A marine white smoker biome comprises regions of the marine hydrothermal vent biome characterised by lightly hued plumes, typically containing barium, calcium, and silicon. These vents tend to have lower temperature plumes when compared to black smoker environments.

label: marine ultramafic hydrothermal vent biome
definition: A marine ultramafic hydrothermal vent biome comprises regions of themarine  hydrothermal vent biome hosted on ultramafic (also referred to as ultrabasic) rocks. Ultramafic rocks are igneous and meta-igneous rocks with very low silica content (less than 45%), generally >18% MgO, high FeO, low potassium, and are composed of usually greater than 90% mafic minerals  (dark colored, high magnesium and iron content). The Earth's mantle is composed of ultramafic rocks.

label: marine basaltic hydrothermal vent biome
definition: A marine basaltic hydrothermal vent biome comprises regions of the marine hydrothermal vent biome hosted on basaltic rocks. Basalt generally has a composition of 45 to 55 wt % SiO2, 2 to 6 wt % total alkalis, 0.5 to 2.0 wt % TiO2, 5 to 14 wt % FeO and 14 wt % or more Al2O3. Contents of CaO are commonly near 10 wt %, those of MgO commonly in the range 5 to 12 wt %.

label: marine algal bloom
definition: A marine algal bloom is a rapid increase or accumulation in the population of algae in a marine system. Typically, only one or a small number of phytoplankton  species are involved. Although there is no officially recognized threshold level, algae can be considered to be blooming at concentrations of hundreds to thousands of cells per milliliter, depending on the severity.

label: kelp forest
definition: Kelp forests are underwater areas with a high density of kelp. They are recognized as one of the most productive and dynamic ecosystems on Earth. Smaller areas of anchored kelp are called kelp beds.

label: sea grass bed
definition: A bed of a marine, saline water body which is covered by one or more speices of seagrass typically belonging to the families Posidoniaceae, Zosteraceae, Hydrocharitaceae, or Cymodoceaceae.

label: particulate matter
definition: Particulate material is an environmental material which is composed of microscopic portions of solid or liquid material suspended in another environmental material.

label: marine wind mixed layer
definition: The upper part of the marine water column with generally uniform properties resulting from wind-driven mixing.

label: marine benthic storm
definition: Benthic storms are strong benthic (near bottom) currents transporting sediment, created by the input of energy (largely kinetic) to the seabed. In regions with high mesoscale eddy activity, benthic storms are frequent and can create isohaline and isothermal conditions extending as much as 1000m above the seafloor.

label: planktonic material
definition: A portion of planktonic material is a portion of environmental material primarily composed of plankton.

label: marine downwelling
definition: A marine downwelling describes a net current of marine surface water towards deeper regions of the water column. Marine downwellings are usually caused by differences in the density (and hence, temperature and salinity) of seawater.

label: marine oxygen minimum zone
definition: A marine water mass which is characterized by having much lower than normal dissolved oxygen concentrations persistently.

label: marine anoxic zone
definition: Marine anoxic zones are areas of marine water that are depleted of dissolved oxygen. This condition is generally found in areas that have restricted water exchange. In most cases, oxygen is prevented from reaching the deeper levels by a physical barrier (sill) as well as by a pronounced density stratification. Anoxic conditions will occur if the rate of oxidation of organic matter by bacteria is greater than the supply of dissolved oxygen.

label: marine current
definition: A water current which is maintained by a continuous, directed movement of marine water, generated by forces caused by breaking waves, wind, Coriolis force, temperature and salinity differences, and tides caused by the gravitational pull of astronomical bodies. Depth contours, shoreline configurations and interaction with other currents influence a current's direction and strength.

label: marine streamer
definition: Marine streamers are tongues of cold water that extend > 100 km offshore from upwelling regions. Enhanced primary productivity may occur in these waters as they are typically more nutrient rich than marine surface waters.

label: mesoscale marine eddy
definition: Mesoscale marine eddies are characterized by currents which flow in a roughly circular motion around the center of the eddy. The sense of rotation of these currents may either be cyclonic or anticyclonic. Ocean eddies are also usually made of water masses that are different to those outside of the eddy. Marine mesoscale eddies are between about 10 and 500 km in diameter, and persist for periods of days to months. They may be formed when an ocean current develops an instability. This instability grows, causing the current to meander, and eventually an eddy is pinched off from the meander.

label: terrigenous sediment
definition: Sediment comprised of weathered continental rocks, wind blown dust, volcanic ash or other terrestrial material.

label: oceanic front
definition: An oceanic front is a narrow zone of enhanced horizontal gradients of water properties (temperature, salinity, nutrients, etc.) that separates broader areas with different water masses or different vertical structure (stratification).

label: marine Taylor column
definition: A marine Taylor column is a Taylor column that is formed in a marine body of water. Currents flowing over shoaling topography such as seamounts are accelerated and destabilised, resulting in Taylor columns. Eddies and internal waves are generated downstream of the topological feature and may extend 1000 m or so above them. This may result in a localised increase in primary production where the Taylor column reaches surface waters.

label: marine oligotrophic desert
definition: An expanse of marine water characterised by low concentrations of nutrients such as phosphate, nitrate as well as organic matter and, hence, low primary productivity. These regions tend to have high dissolved oxygen levels due to a lack of respiration.

label: oceanic gyre
definition: A gyre in oceanography is any large system of rotating ocean currents, particularly those involved with large wind movements. Gyres are caused by the Coriolis Effect; planetary vorticity  along with horizontal and vertical friction, which determine the circulation patterns from the wind curl (torque).

label: marine thermocline
definition: A thermocline which is part of a marine water body.

label: marine chemocline
definition: A marine chemocline is a marine cline caused by a strong, vertical chemistry gradient within a body of marine water. Chemoclines most commonly occur where local conditions favor the formations of anoxic bottom water.

label: marine pycnocline
definition: A pycnocline which is part of a marine water body and composed primarily of sea water.

label: marine nutricline
definition: A nutricline which is part of a marine water body.

label: marine lysocline
definition: The marine lysocline denotes the depth in the ocean below which the rate of dissolution of calcite increases dramatically. As water column depth and therefore pressure increases, the corresponding calcite saturation of seawater decreases and the calcite begins dissolve.

label: pelagic isothermal surface
definition: A roughly planar, pelagic region characterised by equal water temperature.

label: pelagic isohaline surface
definition: A roughly planar, pelagic region characterised by equal salinity.

label: biogenous sediment
definition: Biogenous sediment is derived from living organisms, typically planktonic organisms possessing shells, frustules or coccoliths.

label: pelagic isopycnal surface
definition: A roughly planar, pelagic region characterised by equal water density.

label: subtropical convergence front
definition: A convergence front which is located in a region subject to subtropical climate patterns.

label: deep ocean current
definition: A marine current that generally occurs below the permanent thermocline (where it occurs) or below 400 m depth and that is driven by density and temperature gradients.

label: marine surface current
definition: A marine current bordered by the surface of the water column and the permanent thermocline, where it occurs. Surface currents are mostly wind driven and mostly limited to the top 400 m of the water column. Ocean currents are driven by the circulation of wind above surface waters. Frictional stress at the interface between the ocean and the wind causes the water to move in the direction of the wind. Large ocean currents are a response of the atmosphere and ocean to the flow of energy from the tropics to polar regions. In some cases, currents are transient features and affect only a small area. Other ocean currents are essentially permanent and extend over large horizontal distances.

label: along-front current
definition: A marine surface current that flows along an oceanic front.

label: western boundary current
definition: A warm water, narrow marine surface current flowing from the equator to high latitudes at speeds between 40 and 120 kilometers per day. Western boundary currents are the deepest ocean surface flows, usually extending 1000 meters below the ocean surface.

label: eastern boundary current
definition: A cold water, broad marine surface current flowing from high latitudes to the equator at speeds between 3 and 7 kilometers per day.

label: marine benthic feature
definition: A prominent or distinctive aspect, quality, or characteristic of environments occurring on or along marine benthic environments.

label: permanent marine thermocline
definition: A marine thermocline which separates the marine cold-water sphere from the marine warm-water sphere and which does not dissipate seasonally.

label: seasonal marine thermocline
definition: A marine thermocline which is present below the marine wind mixed layer.

label: marine cold-water sphere
